messageBody:
> But then he switches to the word "The" and how we should
> write it. So he brings up a critical matter, and then limits it to one
> word.

Although Read dodged the bullet with the word "the", there are some
not-necessarily-phonetic standardized spellings mentioned in the QM,
the most conspicuous being the "spell all Rs" rule"
The line "...for Excite, Extreme, Expect with initial vowel Et
easier than It..." is the most frightening. One could take this line
to imply that it is legitimate to use similar sounding vowels that
knowingly do not match ones speech just because that makes writing
easier. I believe this would be a disastrous conclusion to draw and
that the Et before the X letters be viewed as a unique exception.
I further suggest that no conclusions (and especially no general
rules) of pronunciation be drawn from the standardized spellings and
thus that we assume those 60+ words along with the rules for the
letter X and R are the only possible non-phonemic spellings.
Incidentally, I'm not trying to imply here that each QS letter has a
single invariant sound: Read seems rather explicit that #36 covers a
variety of sounds if I'm not mistaken.


> On a final note for tonight, I think my proposal suggets we handle
> problems on a case by case basis. If for example, we need to determine
> that the sit-seat dialect needs to use certain letters to distinguish
> sounds, I see no reason not to state that. We could still use precise
> language. We could say that in such and such a dialect, the words "sit"
> an "seat" are pronounced with the /I/, but that in order to distinguish
> these vowels, speakers in this dialect should either use a standard
> dialect X, or they can use the /I/ sound for X, and the /i/ for X.

A rough QS to IPA chart built by persons of varying accent would
probably be very enlightening: If we find the exact same sound placed
under different QS letters in different accents then I think we have a
very interesting problem. Personally I know of 4 different QS
pronunciation charts (two of them in this group, one at omniglot and
one I've used) Each differs though usually only slightly. Only one
mentions its accent and two seem to contradict over #26 vs #27 and one
maps #6 to the Dutch guttural g.
